standfirst: Foreign minister says the horological initiative is intended to help people find their indigenous roots
headline: Bolivia turns back the clock in bid to rediscover identity and 'southernness'

standfirst: Australian citizen Natalie Lowrey is facing two years in a Malaysian jail after she was arrested while protesting against an Australian-owned mining company on Sunday. People gathered for a protest at the processing plant owned by Lynas and about 16 people were arrested after violence broke out between police and demonstrators.
headline: Australian facing two years' jail for protesting in Malaysia - video

standfirst: South African athlete Oscar Pistorius was not mentally ill when he shot girlfriend Reeva Steenkamp, a panel of experts conclude. The sportsman is surrounded by press as he arrives at Pretoria high court for his trial, which has resumed after a one-month break. Chief prosecutor Gerrie Nel refers to key parts of the conclusions in court, noting that the experts believe Pistorius was capable of appreciating the wrongfulness of his deed when he killed Steenkamp
headline: Pistorius not mentally ill when he shot girlfriend, court hears – video

standfirst: Judge is expected to receive reports by panel of experts who assessed whether athlete has anxiety disorder
headline: Oscar Pistorius to return to dock after psychiatric tests

standfirst: Sydney surfers have a close encounter with a whale. A helicopter's camera caught the footage, which shows a surfer quickly swimming away as the whale flicks its tail.  Surfers are advised to keep at least 100m away from whales. The Department of Environment and Heritage told local media the whale may have been a pregnant female
headline: Sydney surfers have a close encounter with a whale - video

standfirst: Rescuers continue to look for survivors and pull bodies out of the rubble after an 11-storey building collapsed on Saturday near Chennai, southern India. The tower was still being built and fell after workers went inside to shelter from the rain during monsoon season. Building collapses are common in India due to lax regulations and substandard construction
headline: Dozens believed to be trapped after under-construction building collapses in India - video

standfirst: Tower on outskirts of Chennai was under construction when it crumbled, killing at least 11
headline: Dozens trapped as building collapses during monsoon rains in India

standfirst: Village also destroyed in raids by suspected Islamic militants two months after kidnapping of more than 200 schoolgirls
headline: Boko Haram abducts scores of women and girls in northern Nigeria, say locals

standfirst: Rainbow-clad members of the LGBT community gather in Mexico City at the capital's annual gay pride parade on Saturday. Participants say the celebration is important as they call for respect from the rest of the country. According to activists, there have been many reports of homphobic attacks outside the relatively liberal capital
headline: Mexicans celebrate at the annual gay pride parade - video

standfirst: Government wants to build 440 walls along coastline, but some residents believe a concrete fortress is not the answer
headline: Tsunami-proof 'Great Wall of Japan' divides villagers

standfirst: On a street corner by the river, the shots that sparked the first world war were fired. Finally, residents are hoping to lay to rest the ghosts of past conflicts
headline: Sarajevo: city commemorates end to 'a century of conflict', but divisions still run deep

standfirst: Argentinian president's popularity falls as corruption charges against Amado Boudou, and inflation and debt tarnish her government
headline: Cristina Fernández de Kirchner under pressure after vice-president charged

standfirst: British firm Essar Energy's plans for open cast mine in Mahan forest plans could destroy villages and 5m trees.
headline: Indian forest villagers rise up to halt UK firm's bid to clear land for mining

standfirst: Events are held in Sarajevo and Visegrad on Saturday one hundred years after Gavrilo Princip shot and killed the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, Archduke Franz Ferdinand, which sparked the first world war. Protesters in the Bosnian capital are angry that so much money has been spent on centenary celebrations after the country recently experienced devastating floods
headline: Bosnia-Herzegovina marks centenary of Archduke Franz Ferdinand's assassination in Sarajevo - video

standfirst: Gunmen launch long-range attack on aircraft as it lands in Peshawar, leaving one person dead and two injured
headline: Passenger killed in gun attack on Pakistani plane

standfirst: Campaign team says Ghani has beaten rival by more than 1.3m votes, but Abdullah Abdullah withdraws because of alleged fraud
headline: Ashraf Ghani claims Afghan presidential election victory

standfirst: Emergency services hack away at the walls of a cliff gap in eastern China after a 75-year-old tourist fell into the crevice. The man fell into a gap around 30 metres long and just 20-50cm wide. Luckily the tourist's cries for help were heard by passers-by and he was rescued within two hours
headline: 75-year-old tourist rescued after being trapped in narrow cliff gap in China - video

standfirst: Postwar constitution bans use of force in international disputes, which Shinzo Abe says inhibits country's ability to protect itself
headline: Japan PM to overturn pacifist defence policy

standfirst: Conservationists warn biodiversity crisis could result from widespread illegal poisoning of carcasses by poachers
headline: Africa's vulture population in jeopardy following mass poisoning incidents

standfirst: Australia's deputy prime minister Warren Truss says it is 'highly, highly likely' missing Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 was on autopilot before it went missing. The search area for the plane, which disappeared on 8 March with 239 people on board, has been shifted further south in the Indian ocean. Two vessels are currently mapping the sea floor along the arc of the search area
headline: Flight MH370: new search area announced in Indian ocean - video

standfirst: Chief election officer, Ziaulhaq Amarkhil, accused of cheating and fraud is leaving post in 'national interest'
headline: Top Afghan official stands down after vote-rigging claims

standfirst: A cleric and anti-government activist landed in Lahore, Pakistan, on Monday after clashes in Islamabad forced his plane to divert. Tahir-ul-Qadri, who lives in Canada, has travelled to Pakistan to lead a self-proclaimed revolution against the government. Qadri champions religious tolerance and is a divisive figure in the country
headline: Cleric Tahir-ul-Qadri's supporters clash with police ahead of arrival in Pakistan - video

standfirst: North Koreans march through the streets of Pyongyang with banners to commemorate the 64th anniversary of the beginning of the Korean war. State media shows crowds shouting slogans such as 'Down with the US aggressor'. The war started in 1950 when North Korean troops launched a surprise attack into South Korea
headline: North Koreans hold a rally to mark 64 years since the start of the Korean war - video

standfirst: New York judge blocks $500m payment to creditors in ruling that favours 'predatory' hedge funds over debt restructuring plan
headline: US vulture fund ruling pushes Argentina towards second bankruptcy

standfirst: Jogger takes picture of supposed reptile in river Avon near Clifton suspension bridge in fourth 'sighting' of animal
headline: Beast of Bristol resurfaces with fourth snap of 'crocodile'

standfirst: Serbian leaders and Bosnian Serbs stay away from Sarajevo ceremony to mark 100th anniversary of first world war spark
headline: Serbs boycott Archduke Franz Ferdinand assassination centenary

standfirst: Court upholds money-laundering and tax fraud charges against her and husband Urdangarin in first test for brother King Felipe
headline: Princess Cristina corruption case in Spain is given go-ahead

standfirst: Hélène Pastor, a friend of the Monegasque royal family, was shot and killed last month along with her driver
headline: French police arrest daughter of assassinated Monaco heiress

standfirst: Republican senator Thad Cochran narrowly sees off his Tea Party rival, Chris McDaniel, in the Mississippi primary on Tuesday. Cochran says the win reflects a consensus among voters about the need for 'more and better jobs for Mississippi workers'. The result is a relief for the Republican party after a long and at times turbulent primary season
headline: Mississippi primary: Thad Cochran celebrates victory against Tea Party rival - video

standfirst: Controversial businessman Chen Guangbiao angered homeless people in New York after promising them $300 each and failing to deliver
headline: Chinese tycoon's free lunch for homeless New Yorkers backfires

standfirst: Publisher EMI brings copyright claim against video showing singer in military uniform performing track based on We Will Rock You
headline: YouTube removes Nazi-themed Indonesian video based on Queen hit
Antisemitism, Israeli policy and a controversial opera

standfirst: A man in Tokyo set himself alight at a busy intersection on Sunday in an apparent protest against changes made by the Japanese prime minister. Shinzo Abe is shifting the country's defence policy by ending the pacifist constitution. Witnesses say the man was protesting against this before he self-immolated. He is currently in hospital
headline: Japanese man sets himself on fire in apparent anti-government protest - video report

standfirst: Sir William Patey acknowledges west's failure to eradicate poppy crops in Afghanistan as he calls for state-regulated drug trade
headline: Former UK ambassador to Afghanistan calls for legalisation of drugs

standfirst:
US films dominate box office for first time, but concerns raised over threat to artistic freedom

Click to view a gallery of Godzilla films over the years
headline: Hollywood tears through China's cinemas, stirring censorship fears

standfirst: Dilapidated colonial bungalow where the writer was born in 1903 in Motihari, Bihar state, will become world's first Orwell museum
headline: George Orwell's birthplace in India set to become a museum

standfirst: Caustic editorials, cyber-attacks and police displays form part of mainland's response to vote on right of HK to choose own leader
headline: Hong Kong's unofficial pro-democracy referendum irks Beijing

standfirst: 100 years after the Bosnian-Serb radical murdered Austria's Franz Ferdinand the city is still divided on his actions
headline: Villain or hero? Sarajevo is split on archduke's assassin Gavrilo Princip

standfirst: Irish party's leader Michael Martin says Brian Crowley had effectively left the party for joining 'crowd of headbangers'
headline: Fianna Fáil MEP loses whip for joining rightwing European parliament bloc

standfirst: Prosecutors say Wojciech Janowski, Poland's honorary consul to Monaco, admits giving his coach €200,000 to organise Hélène Pastor's killing
headline: Monaco billionaire's son-in-law accused of ordering her murder

standfirst: Producers predict 'disaster' as up to 80% of grapes could be lost following fierce storms in France
headline: French winegrowers fear for harvest after hail batters prized vineyards

standfirst: Deadline moves to 10pm on Friday in apparent attempt to kickstart negotiations with rebels in east of country
headline: Ukraine extends ceasefire by 12 hours

standfirst: Tahir-ul-Qadri refused for hours to leave plane after it was sent to Lahore, and supporters clash with police in Islamabad
headline: Pakistani cleric claims government 'hijack' after flight diverted from capital

standfirst: Almost half million flee planned army action in North Waziristan, with displaced and others accusing government over relief effort
headline: Pakistan 'unprepared' for refugees fleeing operation against Taliban

standfirst: According to new book Blood Feud, 'Hildebeest' is indeed Michelle's nickname for Hillary – and the Obamas and the Clintons hate each other
headline: Hillary Clinton: is she really 'the Hildebeest' to Michelle Obama?

standfirst: Organisers expect 500,000 at rally as residents call for say in choice of chief executive and activists hold unofficial referendum
headline: Hong Kong prepares for mass protest against Beijing control

standfirst: The Japanese prime minister has announced a number of plans including lowering Japan's corporation tax
headline: Shinzo Abe launches 'third arrow' of Japanese economic reform

standfirst: Activists have 'occupied' men's toilets, donned wedding dresses splashed with red and shaved heads to raise awareness
headline: Meet the Chinese women standing up to inequality

standfirst: Clive Palmer talks to Guardian Australia's political editor, Lenore Taylor. The controversial billionaire politician talks about conflicts of interest, emissions reduction targets, climate change, power prices and the briefings and advice he's been given since arriving in Canberra as the leader of the Palmer United party.
headline: Clive Palmer talks to Lenore Taylor: full interview - video

standfirst: Indian state expected to pass draft law giving camels same legal protections as cows after numbers almost halve in past decade
headline: Rajasthan moves to save the camel as population dwindles

standfirst:
Clive Palmer talks to Guardian Australia's political editor, Lenore Taylor, about power prices. Palmer describes his amendment to the carbon repeal as a requirement not a voluntary situation that power companies pass on the savings to the end user. The billionaire said: 'If I was in business I'd just keep the money' and with that in mind he didn't want to leave it to the regulatory boards.
• Watch the full interview
headline: Clive Palmer on power prices: 'If I was in business I'd just keep the money' - video

standfirst: Gorilla Doctors, a multi-national team operating in the heart of the jungle in DR Congo, treating injured and critically ill gorillas as well as caring for orphans at two sanctuaries
headline: The Gorilla Doctors of the Democratic Republic of Congo - in pictures

standfirst: Corruption charges now faced by the sister of Spain's new king are the latest chapter in her and her husband's fall from grace
headline: Princess Cristina and Iñaki Urdangarin – from media darlings to royal outcasts

standfirst: Campaigners fighting to protect Tuscan countryside are pitted against bosses arguing new rules will ruin historic industry
headline: Marble quarries shut over environment plan firms claim will cost 10,000 jobs

standfirst: Four monitors from the Organisation for Security and Co-operation in Europe are released on Thursday after being detained by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine for more than a month. Four international observers remain in custody of the rebels. OSCE observers are in Ukraine to monitor an agreement aimed at de-escalating the crisis in the country
headline: Ukrainian rebels release OSCE monitors held for over a month - video

standfirst: Ukrainians gather around the presidential administration building and in Kiev's Independence Square on Sunday to demonstrate against the president's extension of a ceasefire in the east of the country. Petro Poroshenko extended the truce by three days after returning from signing a free trade deal in Brussels. Fighting has continued in eastern Ukraine over the last week despite the ceasefire
headline: Ukrainians protest in Kiev against ceasefire in the east of the country - video

standfirst: Popular Landrieu struggling in the polls as Republicans try to cast November election as vote on Democrats in Washington
headline: Louisiana senator Mary Landrieu faces bumpy ride on the Bayou

standfirst: Thousands of Israelis join a rally in Tel Aviv calling for the release of three teenagers who disappeared in the West Bank on 12 June. The Israeli prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, said on Sunday that no effort would be spared to bring the boys home. The teenagers disappeared as they were hitchhiking home
headline: Thousands join rally in Tel Aviv for missing Israeli teenagers – video

standfirst: Pair from Electronic Frontier Foundation and Greenpeace drift massive dirigible over NSA data center in Bluffdale, Utah
headline: 'Illegal spying below': activists launch airship in protest at NSA surveillance

standfirst: Paralympian accused of murdering his girlfriend on Valentine's Day can be held criminally responsible, court is told
headline: Pistorius was not mentally ill when he shot Reeva Steenkamp, experts find

standfirst: Plane on 'autopilot before crash', with course pointing to likely depressurisation and hypoxia rendering crew unconscious
headline: Flight MH370 investigators consider oxygen starvation as cause of disappearance

standfirst: Experts say waitresses staffing an estimated 100 branches of Pyongyang chain are confined to compounds to prevent escape
headline: North Korean restaurants springing up around Asia to raise money for regime

standfirst:
A vast wetland in Botswana, a prehistoric cave in France and an Inca road crossing six countries are among a host of new sites that have been added to the Unesco world heritage list over the past few days, pushing the total number to 1,007

Read the story: Unesco world heritage list tops 1,000
headline: Unesco world heritage list reaches 1,000 – in pictures

standfirst: Church strikes conciliatory note but synod 'working paper' shows stance on divorce, gay rights and abortion unlikely to change
headline: Vatican says believers are shunning Catholic lifestyle after scandals

standfirst: Special feed to mark 100th anniversary since archduke's fateful assassination will chart diplomatic traffic until declaration of war
headline: Foreign Office to 'live' tweet key events leading up to the first world war

standfirst: Clive Palmer has announced that his Palmer United party  senators will vote to repeal the carbon tax if savings are passed on to the average Australian, and will support an emissions trading scheme. In a joint press conference with former US presidential candidate Al Gore, Palmer said his party would move to amend the repeal legislation to force producers to pass on savings to consumers.
headline: Clive Palmer says he will vote to repeal carbon tax – video

standfirst: Baroness Warsi says ministers intend to discuss use of slaves to produce supermarket prawns after Guardian investigation
headline: UK to raise slavery concerns with Thailand after prawn exposé

standfirst: Police surround a building in Kreuzberg where a group of asylum seekers are protesting against their treatment in Germany
headline: Asylum seekers in standoff with police at Berlin protest

standfirst: At least 23 people were injured after ethnic Albanians clashed with police on Sunday in the ethnically-divided town of Mitrovica in northern Kosovo. Protesters were objecting to a newly-reinforced barricade on a bridge over the river which divides the predominantly ethnic Albanians and ethnic Serbs
headline: Violence breaks out in Kosovo's ethnically-divided town of Mitrovica - video

standfirst: Sergei Glazyev tells BBC before the signing in Brussels that Petro Poroshenko lacks legitimacy to make the deal
headline: Vladimir Putin's adviser calls Ukrainian president a 'Nazi' as EU deal signed

standfirst: Wives of minister and parliamentary speaker arrested after alleged baby-trafficking syndicate uncovered in west Africa
headline: Wives of top Niger politicians held over child trafficking

standfirst: Publisher says Chinese firms have turned down translation rights and major importer refuses to distribute English copies
headline: Hillary Clinton's Hard Choices faces effective ban in China

standfirst: Villagers pack the court to applaud woman given two years in prison for trying to prevent land grabs and illegal demolition
headline: Champion of Chinese farmers' rights jailed for forging official documents

standfirst: Handover of the number two military job in Afghanistan comes as Taliban fighters launch attacks in Helmand province
headline: UK military cedes senior post in Kabul as troops pull out

standfirst: Józef Wesołowski, who was recalled to Rome by Pope Francis amid allegations that he paid for sex with minors, found guilty in canonical trial
headline: Vatican's ex-ambassador to Dominican Republic defrocked

standfirst: The incident involved four British nationals, two Turkish passengers, and the Turkish driver
headline: Two British people killed while on Jeep safari in Turkey

standfirst: The 2014 Pyongyang Spring International Trade Fair doubled in size this year, according to state media. Aram Pan toured stalls selling the latest technology, all for foreign currency
headline: From rice cookers to robots: shopping for the latest gadgets in North Korea

standfirst: Jordanian court clears Islamist cleric who was subject of 12-year UK deportation fight of conspiracy charge relating to 1998 plot
headline: Abu Qatada cleared in Jordan of 1998 terrorist bomb plot

standfirst: Fresh claims over use of overseas territory of Diego Garcia as secret jail for terrorist suspects
headline: UK urged to tell all on US rendition flights

standfirst: Photographs from the Guardian Eyewitness series
headline: Eyewitness: Bangladesh

standfirst: Ford delivers tearful speech and apologises for mistakes following two months in treatment for drug and alcohol addiction
headline: Rob Ford returns to work and vows to remain as Toronto mayor

standfirst: Most services from UK to France will continue but airlines warn of potential delays to all flights crossing French airspace
headline: UK flights could be hit by French air traffic controllers' strike

standfirst: Soldiers from Ukraine's military explore a camp they seized from pro-Russian separatists in a raid on Tuesday. The takeover comes during a temporary ceasefire between the Ukrainian government and the rebels. According to reports, a Ukrainian helicopter has also been shot down by separatists since the ceasefire began
headline: Ukrainian military seize pro-Russian camp in Donetsk - video

standfirst: Kiev to sign association agreement with European Union, which Viktor Yanukovych backed away from in November
headline: Ukraine set to sign EU pact that sparked revolution

standfirst: Naftali Frankel, Gilad Shaar and Eyal Yifrach were kidnapped while hitchhiking back from their religious schools
headline: Bodies of three missing Israeli teenagers found in West Bank

standfirst: A Jordanian court ruled on Thursday that international terror suspect Abu Qatada is not guilty of terrorism offences relating to an alleged 1998 bomb plot. The UK sent the radical Islamist cleric back to Amman in 2013 on the promise that the court would not use evidence obtained by torture. Qatada will receive the verdict for a second set of charges later in the year
headline: Radical Islamist cleric Abu Qatada cleared of terrorism offences in Jordan - video

standfirst: The latest stunt by flamboyant Chinese businessman Chen Guangbiao backfired on Wednesday after he promised 200 homeless people $300 each ... but then failed to pay up. Chen, famed for his attention-grabbing philanthropy, had promised to donate the money over a free lunch at the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park. Unfortunately the cash never materialised
headline: Chinese businessman Chen Guangbiao promises homeless New Yorkers $300 each … but fails to pay – video

standfirst: Some patients are innocents caught in the crossfire – some the very ones who shoot, says David Rothstein, a paediatric surgeon working with MSF in Bangui, on Warscapes
headline: Central African Republic – surgeon's diary from a country on the brink

standfirst: Thousand flee homes in at least 25 towns and villages in Lofa and Gbarpolu, the second such invasion in five years
headline: Liberia caterpillar plague causes mass evacuation and crop destruction

standfirst: Unprecedented numbers are risking their lives to reach Europe, and local authorities in coastal communities where they land are struggling to cope. Lizzy Davies reports from Catania while photographer Massimo Sestini accompanied the Italian navy on its rescue missions earlier this month, offering a rare up-close glimpse of the men, women and children who make the dangerous trip to start a new life
headline: Europe's migrant influx: 'we need help but we don’t know where from'

standfirst: Pope refuses to commit himself to raising status of women in Catholic church and makes 'joke' about female subservience
headline: Pope Francis jokes 'woman was from a rib' as he avoids vow to reform church

standfirst: Zindagi TV hopes first legally available broadcasts of Pakistani dramas may help to bring estranged neighbours closer together
headline: Indians to get peek into daily lives of Pakistanis with new soap opera channel

standfirst: St Peter's Cricket Club to play Royal Household at Windsor and Church of England in shadow of Canterbury cathedral
headline: Vatican cricket team to go head-to-head with Anglican rivals on UK tour

standfirst: Corpses discovered off coast of Sicily during rescue mission with cause of death believed to be asphyxiation
headline: Thirty dead bodies found on migrant boat bound for Italy

standfirst: EU and human rights and privacy groups welcome pledge, which follows pressure in wake of Snowden revelations
headline: US to extend privacy protection rights to EU citizens

standfirst: With Ukrainian soldiers buying their own uniforms, volunteers are now stepping in to equip the troops facing rebels in the east
headline: Ukrainians crowdfund to raise cash for 'people's drone' to help outgunned army

standfirst: Leader of France's Front National concedes defeat in bid to secure extra speaking time, staff and funds from EU budget
headline: Marine Le Pen fails to form far-right bloc in European parliament

standfirst: Ukraine's president Petro Poroshenko signs a free-trade agreement with the EU and fellow former Soviet republics Georgia and Moldova on Friday. The former Ukrainian president's failure to sign the agreement last year led to his ousting after months of protests in Kiev. The agreement has angered Russia, with one adviser to Vladimir Putin calling Ukrainian leaders 'Nazis'
headline: Ukraine signs a free-trade agreement with Europe in a step towards the west - video

standfirst: Two weeks since teenagers vanished, huge search has raised questions over how much operation is aimed at crushing Hamas
headline: Hunt for missing Israeli boys stirs up familiar recriminations

standfirst: Photographs from the Guardian Eyewitness series
headline: Eyewitness: Colorado

standfirst: Churches set alight in attack by suspected Islamist extremists on village close to town from where schoolgirls were kidnapped
headline: At least 30 die in Nigeria village attacks

standfirst: An examination of how countries around the world affected by civil war or internal conflict have approached justice
headline: Special report: Truth, justice and reconciliation

standfirst: Andrew Laming becomes the second politician to take to the Guardian Australia whiteboard to help explain the controversial 2014 Australian federal budget. Laming breaks down what he calls an unsustainable level of debt while explaining the carbon tax, fuel rebate, commonwealth scholarships, co-payments and cuts to the ABC and SBS.
headline: Budget 2014: Whiteboard explainer with Andrew Laming - video

standfirst: Dentist and his wife sue British Airways for booking them tickets to Caribbean island rather than Spanish city 6,000 miles away
headline: Alleged BA mixup sent US couple to Grenada instead of Granada

standfirst: Exhibition at French museum to tell story of 1914 battle which forced German retreat and prevented enemy from taking Paris
headline: Exhibition to tell story of forgotten British role in Battle of Marne

standfirst: Tony O'Reilly begs court for time to repay millions after being labelled insolvent after his businesses crashed
headline: Bank pulls the plug on Irish billionaire who owned Independent

standfirst: Authorities reluctant to renew passport of Harriet, 10, as name is not on approved list of 3,565
headline: Icelandic girls can't be called Harriet, government tells family

standfirst: Murder of archduke would have no 'salient effect' on Europe, declared Manchester Guardian, just 37 days before war erupted
headline: How the Guardian played down the assassination that sparked world war

standfirst: President cancels ruling allowing Russian troops to cross border but Ukrainian helicopter is shot down as fighting continues
headline: Putin removes threat of military intervention after Ukraine ceasefire

standfirst: Pro-Ukrainian supporters call on France to cancel €1.2bn deal to deliver warships with amphibious assault capabilities to Russia
headline: Russian navy in Saint-Nazaire to train on new ships amid Ukraine tensions

standfirst: Petro Poroshenko, in Brussels to sign EU association agreement, says separatists in Donetsk and Luhansk are under Putin's control
headline: Ukrainian president accuses Russia of doing nothing to end 'disastrous' war

standfirst: Gay rights activists say aim was to repeat lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender rally targeted by homophobes last year
headline: Georgian pro-Russia group 'planned fake pride march to scupper EU deal'

standfirst: Ramadan, the Muslim month of fasting, begins on Sunday. Are you participating? Share your experiences and photos with us
headline: Ramadan: share your photos and stories

standfirst: Freedom Summer, a program that brought mostly northern white college students to Mississippi to register black voters, turns 50. Three young civil rights workers were slain by Ku Klux Klan members on a country road in Neshoba County prompting a massive FBI search for them and their killers. The bodies of Andrew Goodman, James Chaney and Michael Schwerner were found two months later buried in an earthen dam
headline: Mississippi Freedom Summer: 50 years on – in pictures

standfirst: Campaigners call for release of 29-year-old Mubarak Bala, who lives in Kano in Nigeria's predominantly Muslim north
headline: Nigerian man is locked up after saying he is an atheist

standfirst: Number of animal rights activists descending on Yulin may be small, but opposition against eating dog meat has broadened
headline: Chinese dog-eating festival backlash grows

standfirst: Photographs from the Guardian Eyewitness series
headline: Eyewitness: Mecavnik, western Serbia
Khrushchev flats provided housing for all

standfirst: Ukraine crisis seen as game-changer, with only four countries meeting US target of spending 2% of GDP on defence
headline: US presses Nato members to increase defence spending

standfirst: More than 20 firefighters free exchange student from the artwork Chacán-Pi (Making Love) by Fernando de la Jara in Tübingen
headline: US student is rescued from giant vagina sculpture in Germany

standfirst: A group of Christians, Muslims and Jews in Berlin is trying to crowdsource funds to build a place where they can all worship together. But are all religious communites backing the ambitious project?
headline: Berlin's House of One: a church, a mosque and a synagogue under one roof

standfirst: Police arrest 91 in raids on suspected Cosa Nostra after alleged mobster claims great-uncle murdered NY officer Joe Petrosino
headline: Italian police 'solve' suspected mafia killing of US detective in 1909

standfirst: Issue of whether to stay or go has become a hot topic in liberal press with some spurred on by annexation of Crimea
headline: From Russia with love: new wave of emigration sparks debate

standfirst: Employers' leader John Cridland makes case for continued European Union membership after Cameron's Juncker defeat
headline: EU exit will harm UK, says leading British industry group

standfirst: EU heads of state met in Belgium this week, nearly all of them support Juncker's presidency
headline: Unlike David Cameron, Gavrilo Princip had fellow plotters

standfirst: European leaders arrive at a meeting in Brussels on Friday ahead of an expected decision on a nominee for the president of the European Commission. The vote is mired in controversy as David Cameron stands against his fellow leaders in not supporting the favourite for the role, Luxembourg's Jean-Claude Juncker. Cameron believes Juncker will limit the powers of EU nations and increase the powers of Brussels
headline: David Cameron continues opposition of Jean-Claude Juncker at EU summit - video

standfirst: Like much of the country, Tabarka's economic fortunes have suffered as holidaygoers have failed to return after revolution
headline: On Tunisia's tourist coast, frustration lurks behind the tranquil vistas

standfirst: Two police officers killed as they tried to defuse bombs outside presidential palace, with several people wounded
headline: Cairo hit by bombings on first anniversary of anti-Morsi protests

standfirst: Meriam Ibrahim, the Christian Sudanese woman detained when she tried to travel to the US after being released from death row, is released on Thursday for a second time. Ibrahim was originally sentenced to hang for apostasy because she born a Muslim but raised a Christian. She has been released on bail and cannot leave the country unless the charges are dropped
headline: Christian convert Meriam Ibrahim freed again from Sudanese prison - video

standfirst: Ibrahim apprehended with husband and two children at Khartoum airport one day after she was released
headline: Sudan death row woman Meriam Ibrahim detained again

standfirst: Voters are faced with an overwhelming range of candidates and issues, with the spectre of civil war hanging over proceedings
headline: Disillusionment mars Libya's national poll

standfirst: Avigdor Lieberman says Assad's forces will have to 'pay the price'  for anti-tank missile that killed 13-year-old boy
headline: Israeli foreign minister says Syrian army's missile killed boy in Golan

standfirst: President Bronislaw Komorowski distances himself from the PM, Donald Tusk, over embarrassing transcripts published in Wprost
headline: Polish government expletive tapes lead to snap election rumours

standfirst: German chancellor promises review of nomination process as Sweden's Reinfeldt says post-vote paper allows EU flexibility
headline: Merkel offers Cameron olive branch after Juncker vote

standfirst: The bandwagon that appointed Juncker has been rolling since at least 2009
headline: The EU's 'democratic' system that elected a president nobody wants

standfirst: Prime minister's lonely bid to remake the EU to his liking has ended in disaster, and strengthened the hand of Eurosceptics
headline: Humiliating defeat for David Cameron pushes Britain towards EU exit

standfirst: Prime minister attacks the frontrunner for the leadership, who he says has been dedicated to increasing the power of Brussels
headline: Juncker is wrong person for European commission job, says David Cameron

standfirst: Prime minister says 'railroading through' candidate for European commission will have grave impact on British public opinion
headline: Cameron tells EU it may live to regret Jean-Claude Juncker appointment

standfirst: Prime minister suffers humiliating defeat as EU leaders vote 26-2 in favour of nomination for European commission president
headline: David Cameron loses Jean-Claude Juncker vote

standfirst: In Ypres most of the 28 EU leaders will unenthusiastically go along with Juncker, but he is a miscalculation for Europe
headline: Europe is shrinking and Juncker is a symbol of its quiet-life parochialism

standfirst: An Egyptian court sentenced three al-Jazeera journalists on Monday on charges of aiding the Muslim Brotherhood which the government has designated a 'terrorist organisation'. Australian Peter Greste and Canadian-Egyptian Mohamed Fahmy were each sentenced to seven years and local producer Baher Mohamed was given a 10-year sentence. Independent observers have said there is a complete lack of evidence in the trial
headline: Egyptian court hands down prison sentences to three al-Jazeera journalists - video

standfirst: Juris and Lois Greste, the parents of Australian al-Jazeera journalist Peter Greste who was sentenced to seven years in an Egyptian prison, say their son's verdict has left them 'shattered'. Greste's father says 'this is a dark time, not only for our family, but for journalism generally'. Greste and his two colleagues were convicted for aiding a 'terrorist organisation' which they deny
headline: Parents of jailed al-Jazeera journalist Peter Greste speak of their devastation - video

standfirst: During the trial of Peter Greste, Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed the Guardian witnessed a litany of faults in prosecution
headline: Six flaws in the case against three jailed al-Jazeera journalists

standfirst: At least 14 rockets reported to have been fired, with no injuries reported, as tensions in the region escalate
headline: Gaza rockets strike southern Israel

standfirst: Appeal court orders cancellation of death sentence for Christian woman for apostasy, which sparked international outcry
headline: Sudan announces release of Meriam Ibrahim from death row

standfirst: Gunmen broke into Benghazi home on day of general election, killing lawyer, wounding security guard and abducting husband
headline: Libya in shock after murder of human rights activist Salwa Bugaighis

standfirst: Authorities accused of purging opposition on opening day of court case over illegal protest
headline: Novelist Ahdaf Soueif condemns 'war on young' as Egypt activists stand trial
It's important to recognise the impact Islamism is having in the UK

standfirst: Islamic Federation of Catalonia says Qatari emir is backing €2.2bn plan for mosque on site of disused Plaza Monumental
headline: Barcelona bullfighting ring may become Europe's largest mosque

standfirst: A survey shows more than half are satisfied with their lives and think positively about their employment prospects
headline: Germans reject their joyless image to become Europe's optimists

headline: Cameron's Juncker concerns are shared by European leaders, says Osborne

standfirst: Shadow chancellor calls efforts to stop Juncker's appointment as European commission president a 'catastrophe for Britain'
headline: Cameron's attempt to block Juncker was 'cack-handed', says Ed Balls

standfirst: Binyamin Netanyahu claims creation of Kurdish state would aid in formation of alliance of moderate powers in Middle East
headline: Israel's prime minister backs Kurdish independence

standfirst: At least 19 people were injured in southern Beirut, Lebanon, on Tuesday after an explosion next to a cafe where football fans were watching the World Cup. The blast killed the bomber, but nobody else was seriously injured. The bombing took place in a mainly Shia Muslim area of Beirut three days after a failed attempt to kill a senior security official
headline: Beirut residents wounded in suicide bombing while watching World Cup - video

standfirst: Google et al happy to comply with law, but systems aren't set up to prevent those videos, hashtags and accounts getting online
headline: Taking down Isis material from Twitter or YouTube not as clear cut as it seems

standfirst: Mohamed Fahmy donates £1,200 to fund set up by government for citizens to help ailing economy, in attempt to win local support
headline: Convicted al-Jazeera journalist makes donation to Egyptian state fund

standfirst: Remaining 8% of Assad's acknowledged chemical weapons and precursors arsenal sent to Italy as UN deadline draws near
headline: Syria hands over final chemical weapons for destruction

standfirst: Cairo's decision to impose seven-year sentences has weakened Kerry after he interceded on the journalists' behalf
headline: John Kerry snubbed by Egypt's heavy jail sentences for  al-Jazeera journalists

standfirst: Husband of Christian woman whose apostasy death sentence was overturned says she and children doing well
headline: Sudanese woman Meriam Ibrahim 'safe and well' in US embassy

standfirst: John Kerry embarrassed by long jail terms handed down just a day after the US restored military and economic aid to Egypt
headline: Al-Jazeera journalists' stiff sentences prompt international outrage at Egypt

standfirst: As three journalists are moved to a new jail in Egypt, Greste's brother relays his call for their story to be kept alive
headline: Peter Greste: don't abandon me and other jailed al-Jazeera journalists

standfirst: Leading journalists condemn judiciary's sentences and fear for consequences on press freedom in turbulent times
headline: Egypt 'declaring journalism a crime' by jailing al-Jazeera correspondents

standfirst: Campaign triggered after woman imprisoned for marrying a Christian was sentenced to 100 lashes and hanging for apostasy
headline: Sudan death row's Meriam Ibrahim released after international outcry

standfirst: Diplomatic wrangling over case continues after freed woman is detained for trying to fly to US on papers issued by South Sudan
headline: Meriam Ibrahim: Khartoum summons South Sudanese and US ambassadors

standfirst: Devices purported to identify and cure hepatitis and HIV set to be put to use have been delayed citing 'further testing'
headline: Egyptian military backtracks on Aids cure claims

standfirst: Peter Greste, Mohamed Fahmy and Baher Mohamed of Al-Jazeera English sentenced on terrorism-related charges
headline: Al-Jazeera journalists jailed for seven years in Egypt

standfirst: Footage of young children carrying rifles with Isis fighters has sparked concerns the militant Islamist group is recruiting young people. The video shows two boys brandishing the guns as part of a convoy in which Isis paraded weapons and vehicles seized from the Iraqi army in Mosul. Human rights groups say the rebels have recruited children as young as 14 in the past
headline: Iraq: gun-toting children paraded in Isis convoy - video

standfirst: Iraqis from a predominantly-Christian town south of Mosul flee from fighting between Kurdish forces and Isis militants. The UN's refugee agency says as many as 10,000 people have fled the Christian communities of Qaraqosh since violence broke out. Isis captured Mosul, Iraq's second-largest city, in a sweep of northern Iraq in early June
headline: Thousands of Iraqi Christians flee from fighting between Isis and Kurdish forces - video

standfirst: Nomination could pave way for naming of a new president, but position of prime minister remains undecided
headline: Iraqi MPs under pressure to nominate speaker

standfirst: Several thousand displaced Iraqis arrive at a refugee camp near Irbil on Thursday after fleeing Mosul, the second-largest city in Iraq which was taken by Isis militants last week. Isis have released footage apparently showing burning military vehicles after clashes in Mosul. The Iraqi governnment says it has retaken the Baiji oil refinery
headline: Displaced Iraqis struggle in refugee camps as the military regains control of the Baiji refinery - video

standfirst: Staff at much-needed hospital given a month's notice because charity needs established funding partner to keep facility open
headline: Syria charity blames red tape for closure of Aleppo hospital

standfirst: Department told of lax oversight at firm with $1bn contract to protect US diplomats weeks before Blackwater guards killed 17 Iraqis
headline: Blackwater considered itself above the law, US state department was warned

standfirst: Parents anxiously await news after teenagers abducted from bus while travelling from Kobani to Aleppo to take exams
headline: Up to 186 Kurdish students kidnapped by Isis in northern Syria

standfirst: Troops and helicopter gunships used to try to recapture city from Sunni militants, as talks begin between political parties
headline: Iraqi forces launch attacks on Tikrit

standfirst: Pentagon says flights are to protect US military contingent that is assisting Iraqi forces in fight against Isis
headline: US flying armed drones in Iraq

standfirst: Despite international pressure, Nouri al-Maliki says calls are an attack on Iraq's constitution and young democratic process
headline: Iraqi prime minister rejects pleas for government of 'national salvation'

standfirst: Now revived by the jihadists of the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (Isis), this old-new political-religious entity has become a potent weapon in a digital propaganda war
headline: What is a caliphate?

standfirst: At 16, Reyaad Khan wanted to rid the world of evil; at 20, he was in Syria, recruiting British Muslims to fight for Isis
headline: Jihadist who wanted to be British PM

standfirst: She talks of their love, her grief and how she censored the media so he would not read bad news about his beloved ANC
headline: Mandela's widow, Graça Machel, speaks of her loss for the first time

standfirst: From Cameron and Coulson to European privacy, insecticides and new miniature mammals – a roundup of the week's news
headline: 10 things we learned this week

standfirst: Iran, the US and even the Shia militias who fought the American invasion are turning uneasily to each other
headline: New alliances bring old enemies together as Isis advances in Iraq

standfirst: Residents of Baquba, an hour from Baghdad, are on the frontline of a sectarian showdown that is fast becoming another civil war
headline: Iraqis caught in a state of fear between Isis and Shia militias

headline: Iraq crisis: answers to readers' questions about a nation on the brink

headline: Iraq crisis: Maliki welcomes Syrian air strikes

standfirst: Human Rights Watch says it has identified the sites of mass executions in Iraq earlier this month after comparing satellite images to photos released by Isis militants. Analysis shows the executions of between 160 and 190 men took place in a field near a former palace of Saddam Hussein. Recent satellite images have shown no bodies, which may have been buried or moved elsewhere
headline: Human Rights Watch identifies Isis execution sites based on satellite images - video

standfirst: John Kerry, the US secretary of state, urges the Kurdish president to work with the Iraqi government during a visit to Irbil on Tuesday. Though Kurdish president Massoud Barzani has been quoted as saying that Kurds would like to be independent, Kerry believes the country's best hope of peace lies in unity. Barzani has blamed the policies of the prime minister, Nouri al-Maliki, for the violence in Iraq
headline: John Kerry urges Kurdish leaders to work with Iraqi government to combat Isis - video

standfirst:
Jihadist group challenges al-Qaida as it changes name to Islamic State and pledges to free Palestine in video

• Isis declares caliphate in Iraq and Syria – live updates
headline: Isis announces Islamic caliphate in area straddling Iraq and Syria

standfirst: The US secretary of state pledges support for Iraq's security forces as they battle against Islamist insurgents Isis. John Kerry claims Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki has committed to forming a new government in Iraq from 1 July. It comes after Barack Obama offered up 300 American advisers to help co-ordinate the fight
headline: John Kerry: support for Iraq will be 'intense' - video

standfirst: As Iraq's government teeters before Isis insurgents, the Kurds now control the oil hub of Kirkuk – and have national ambitions
headline: Iraqi Kurds strengthen their positions while Isis advances on Baghdad

standfirst:
• Kerry visits Irbil as Kurdish president describes 'new reality'
  • Kurdistan makes $100m international oil sale
  • Iraqi cabinet suspends government pay in hostile zones
  • UN says more than 1,000 deaths in Iraq in June
  • Conflicting reports on control of Baiji refinery
  • Reader Q&A
  • Read the latest summary
headline: Iraq crisis: US troops arrive in Baghdad

standfirst: Isis militants declare an Islamic state, or 'caliphate' in an area straddling the border between Iraq and Syria. Iraqi government forces are increasing security around Baghdad, and launching attacks to try to claw back some of the territory gained by the rebels. Meanwhile families fleeing the violence take refuge in makeshift camps
headline: Isis rebels declare new Islamic state as Iraq tightens security around Baghdad - video

standfirst: Secretary of state reiterates US support for Iraqi army after talks with Maliki, but 'need for less divisive PM' made clear in private
headline: John Kerry urges Iraq's leaders to stand united in face of Islamist insurgency

standfirst: Footage aired on Iraqi state television apparently shows Iraqi government troops launching attacks on Isis militants, east of Tikrit. During the brief military operation soldiers claim to uncover a weapons storage facility and regain two trucks that had been taken by militants after they swept through large parts of northern Iraq on 11 June
headline: Iraqi government troops battle Isis militants – video

standfirst: The shadow justice minister Sadiq Khan says more needs to be done to prevent British Muslims from going to the Middle East to fight. Khan says Muslims in the UK need to know the real version of Islam to resist extremist messages. The shadow justice minister adds that it only takes one person to continue violent behaviour in this country for there to be danger to Brits. Khan's comments come after British Islamists in Iraq released a video to recruit others
headline: Sadiq Khan: British Muslims need to resist extremist messages - video

standfirst: Air strikes may spell end of what has often looked like a mutually beneficial relationship between Syrian regime and jihadists
headline: Assad and Maliki unite against common enemy Isis

headline: Isis declares caliphate in Iraq and Syria

standfirst: Vengeful Shia militias add atrocities to Sunni-led militant group's brutal killings with casualties crossing sectarian lines
headline: Isis onslaught in Iraq claims terrible toll of victims on both sides of divide

standfirst: The extremist jihadist group leading the insurgency against the Iraqi government is using apps, social media and even a feature-length movie to intimidate enemies, recruit new followers and spread its message. And its rivals – including foreign governments – are struggling to keep up
headline: Who is behind Isis's terrifying online propaganda operation?

standfirst: US secretary of state calls on Kurds to stand with Baghdad as battle with Isis for Baiji oil refinery continues
headline: John Kerry: US troop deployment to Iraq is not intervention

standfirst: Prime minister denies coordination with Assad as Iraqi forces raid Tikrit and Kurdish leader makes symbolic visit to Kirkuk
headline: Isis: Maliki hails Syrian air raids in Iraq as leaving both states 'winners'
